full_text: Screened by NARA, 9/14/2023 Part 4. Eligibility to Sponsor You must be a U.S. citizen or national or a lawful permanent resident. If you are a joint spor or you must provide proof of your status. If you are a U.S. citizen attach a copy of a docum nt proving your status such as a U.S. passport, birth certificate. or certificate of naturalization. If you are a lawful permanent resident, attach a copy of both sides of your Alien Registration Card (Form I-551). 10 determination of your eligibility to sponsor an immigrant will be based on an evaluation of your demonstrated ability 16 maintain the sponsored immigrant(s) at or above 125 percent of the Fedc. al poverty line (100 percent If you are a petitioner sponsoring your spouse or child and you are on active duty In the U.S. Armed Forces). The assessment of your a my to provide for a sponsored Immigrant will Include your current employment, household size (Including the number ! immigrants being sponsored). and household income as shown on the last three Federal Income tax returns. Assets that TC readily converted to cash and that can be made available for the support of sponsored Immigrants if necessary. including any such assets of sponsored immigrants. may also be considered. The greatest weight in determining eligibility will be placed on current employment and household Income. If a petitioner $ inable to demonstrate ability to meet the stated Income and asset requirements, a joint sponsor who can meet the income requirement is needed. Failure to provide adequate evidence of income and/or assets or a joint sponsor will result in denial of the immigrant's application for ar. immigrant visa or adjustment to permanent resident status.
